cont.entity_a: Improves photo quality significantly when transitioning from JPEG/automatic to RAW/manual. Produces crisp images with good depth in portraits. Takes sharper photos than more expensive lenses. Great for low light situations and produces crisp images.
cont.entity_b: Takes amazing pictures with 2.8 aperture. Tack-sharp images and great bokeh, especially for portraits. Phenomenal results in low light with Sony video cameras.

cont.entity_a: Autofocus is not supported on Nikon D5600; requires AF-S for autofocus. No internal AF motor; manual focus required on bodies without focusing motor. Some issues with autofocus on certain models; requires manual focus. Fast and accurate autofocus, works well on D750. Noisy when focusing. Does not focus on entry-level bodies.
cont.entity_b: Fast and quiet SSM feature. AF is slightly faster compared to E-Mount 70-200GM F/2.8.

cont.entity_a: Built like a tank. Lightweight, mostly plastic construction; may crack if dropped. Optical performance is excellent but build quality is poor. Plastic build but offers great value for the price. Poorly made with loose tolerances.
cont.entity_b: Build quality and image quality justify the price.

cont.entity_a: Not compatible with Nikon D3400. Performs better on crop sensor than full frame.
cont.entity_b: Worth its price for high-end cameras, especially full-frame.

cont.entity_a: Became the 'standard' lens for the user, only changing when other lenses are needed. Works well for both indoor and outdoor shots on various Nikon models.
Does not come with directions, leading to initial setup challenges.
Minor sun flares occur when shooting around sunrise or sunset.
cont.entity_b: Intermittent overexposure issue resolved with replacement.
